awd_titl_txt: CAREER: High Performance Spatial Queries and Analytics for Spatial Big Data
awd_abstract_narration:
The rise of big data is changing our way of thinking about the world by providing new insights and creating new forms of value. The challenges for big data come not only from the volume but also the complexity, such as the multi-dimensional nature of spatial data. In this CAREER project, we will deliver a scalable and efficient spatial big data processing system that can take advantage of fast increasing processing power of computers and their latest supporting programming environments. This software can be used for a variety of applications in medical image processing and in GIS (Geographical Information Systems),  e.g., for city planning, transportation planning, disaster response, military planning.

The fundamental goal of this CAREER project is to address the research challenges for delivering a high performance software system for spatial queries and analytics of spatial big data on MapReduce and CPU-GPU hybrid platforms, promote the use of the created open source software to support problem solving in multiple disciplines, and educate the next generation workforce in big data. Specifically, the following research aims will be pursued in this project: 1) Create new spatial data processing methods and pipelines with spatial partition level parallelism through MapReduce and propose multi-level indexing methods to accelerate spatial data processing; 2) Research two critical components to enable data parallelism: effective and scalable spatial partitioning in MapReduce, and query normalization methods for partition effect; 3) Research efficient GPU-based spatial operations to support object level and intra-object level parallelism, and integrate them into MapReduce pipelines; 4) Investigate optimization methods for data processing pipelines, data skew mitigation, and CPU/GPU resource coordination in MapReduce; and 5) Provide declarative spatial queries and create a query translator to  automatically translate the queries into MapReduce applications.

The project will provide a high performance scalable spatial computing infrastructure to be deployed by researchers and application users world-wide from various disciplines, and the source codes will be made open source and fully available.  The project will provide a strong foundation to solve spatial big data problems such as location based services, remote sensing based applications, and map based applications. It will also enable the fast solving of scientific problems such as pathology imaging at large scale. The education activities include a revised undergraduate course with a new spatial big data theme, a revised graduate course with a focus on big data management, involvement of undergraduate, graduate and underrepresented students in research, symposia and science projects for K-12 students, and a software infrastructure to support the education. 

For further information see the project web site: http://fushengwang.net/hadoop-gis

Keywords: spatial big data, MapReduce, CPU-GPU, spatial queries, spatial analytics

por.por_cntn:
Support of high performance queries on large volumes of spatial data has become increasingly important in many application domains, including geospatial problems in numerous disciplines, location based services, and emerging biomedical imaging applications. Besides 2D spatial data,  3D spatial data has been generated at an extreme scale, such as 3D Human BioMolecular Atlas (HuBMAP) and 3D digital pathology.

The CAREER project created a foundation of 2D big spatial data processing at scale with a hybrid spatial database and distributed computing approach,  where an in-memory based spatial query engine can run dynamically for distributed tasks on demand, achieving high scalability. This approach overcomes the limitations from traditional parallel database based approach, including data injection, load balancing and scalability.  Several critical research problems on 2D spatial big data processing were addressed,  including optimal partitioning,  task balancing, and resource-constraint processing through query-rewriting.  Two software systems were created, including Hadoop-GIS [1] and SparkGIS [2].

To further overcome the bottleneck of 2D geometric computation, GPU based spatial querying methods were proposed to take advantage of massive parallelism of GPGPUs, through hybrid vector-raster based spatial data modeling.  This significantly boosts the performance of spatial queries with complex objects, providing optimal spatial modeling for parallel computation and minimizing computations [3].

The project made significant breakthrough on 3D spatial queries at extreme scale, in particular for 3D data from high throughput imaging technologies. Innovative methods proposed include progressive 3D compression, progressive querying methods, and novel indexing methods for complex 3D objects.  The proposed Filter-Progressive-Refine spatial querying paradigm overcomes the limitations of traditional Filter-Refine paradigm spatial querying paradigm and provides a foundation of 3D spatial big data management.  This leads to two software system: iSPEED (approximate 3D spatial queries with multi-level 3D compression) [4] and 3DPro (Progressive 3D Compression and Refinement) [5].  

The project also provides a foundation for contact tracing for combating pandemic, through developing an efficient spatial based system GLINT to support real-time contacting tracing [6]. GLINT provides GPU-based highly efficient real-time contact tracing through spatial proximity queries with temporal constraints using location data of humans.

The project makes major impact not only for GIS, but also for biomedical applications.  This includes GIS and big data driven opioid epidemic research to identify geospatial patterns and disparities of opioid overdose and opioid use disorder, spatial analytics for 3D digital pathology research [7],  and 3D spatial big data management for 3D Human BioMolecular Atlas.

Through this project, a summer research program for K12 students [8] has been established to provide 6-week summer research program for high school students, with participation from more than a dozen faculty. The program has recruited more than 70 high students nationwide since 2017, including students in underrepresented groups and female students (~40%).   It also provides scholarships for applicants who are eligible for the Federal free or reduced lunch program.  Besides, three REU students has been recruited for summer research.

 

[1] Hadoop-GIS: https://github.com/StonyBrookDB/hadoopgis/

[2] SparkGIS: https://github.com/StonyBrookDB/sparkgis/

[3] IDEAL-X: https://github.com/tengdj/IDEAL

[4] iSPEED: https://github.com/StonyBrookDB/iSPEED

[5] 3DPro: https://github.com/tengdj/3DPro

[6]  GLINT: https://github.com/tengdj/GLINT

[7] The I3 Framework: https://i3framework.github.io/

[8] The Computer Science and Informatics Summer Research Experience Program at Stony Brook University (CSIRE): https://bmi.stonybrookmedicine.edu/csire
